author: Jody Macgregor
title: Great moments in PC gaming: Injustice 2's over-the-top super moves
description: You haven't lived until you've seen all four Ninja Turtles clobber Brainiac with their shells.
content:
**Injustice 2**

**Developer:** Netherrealm  
**Year:** 2017

Netherrealm, known for Mortal Kombat, successfully navigated the challenge of developing a superhero game without graphic fatalities in *Injustice 2*. While the game features characters from DC Comics and DLC additions like Hellboy and the Ninja Turtles, it compensates with incredibly elaborate super moves that often defy logic.

For instance, the Flash showcases an extraordinary super move where he grabs his opponent, travels back in time to ancient Egypt to throw them at the Sphinx, and then sends them further back to a T-rex, ultimately creating a paradox before dealing significant damage. Aquaman’s super move is equally impressive, summoning a tidal wave followed by a giant fish monster that devours his opponent, who continues fighting as if nothing happened.

Superhero video games often struggle to capture the exuberance of comic book action, but *Injustice 2* excels by allowing characters like Green Lantern to creatively use their powers. In one sequence, Green Lantern constructs a mech suit piece by piece, using it to inflict damage and fire rockets.

The game’s super moves stand out not just for their spectacle but also for how they encapsulate the joy and excitement of both fighting games and superhero comics, creating memorable moments of exaggerated violence that evoke cheers from players.

author: Hannah Hoolihan
title: Which Magic Puzzle Company Jigsaw Puzzle Should You Buy in 2025?
description: From The Mystic Maze to The Busy Bistro, here are our recommendations for which Magic Puzzles are worth buying in 2025.
content:
**Puzzles from The Magic Puzzle Company offer a unique and engaging experience.** Each jigsaw puzzle features original art and a surprise ending that enhances the storytelling aspect. Here are some of the notable puzzles worth trying:

1. **The Mystic Maze (Series One)** - This 1,000-piece puzzle, illustrated by Boya Sun, follows a character in a yellow outfit searching for a lost friend in an enchanted maze. **Surprise Ending**: The character finds their lost friend.

2. **The Sunny City (Series One)** - Created by Felicia Chiao, this vibrant 1,000-piece puzzle depicts a bustling city with bright oranges and yellows. **Surprise Ending**: Big flowers bloom in the city center.

3. **The Happy Isles (Series One)** - Illustrated by Sarah Becan, this puzzle features island paradises and invites you to discover the fate of its inhabitants. **Surprise Ending**: A sea monster causes trouble in The Happy Isles.

4. **The Crystal Caves (Series Two)** - This colorful 1,000-piece puzzle by Odsanyu explores an ancient rivalry between crystals and mushrooms. **Surprise Ending**: Crystals and mushrooms become friends in a triangular area within the cave.

5. **The Forest Feast (Series Two)** - Featuring art by Sanne-Marie Kohlmann, this puzzle allows you to reveal the inspiration behind an epic feast. 

These puzzles offer not only a fun challenge but also a magical experience that culminates in surprising conclusions.

author: ted.litchfield@futurenet.com (Ted Litchfield)
title: Avowed could have been Obsidian's Redfall, with a Destiny plus Skyrim co-op multiplayer vision scrapped early in a grueling 6-year development
description: The great game we got instead is apparently selling well, with DLC and a sequel on the table.
content:
In a recent interview with Bloomberg, Avowed director Carrie Patel discussed the challenging development cycle of the RPG from Obsidian. Initially conceived as a seamless open world with co-op or live service multiplayer, the game underwent a reboot after two years of preproduction. Development, which began in 2018 before Obsidian's acquisition by Microsoft, faced numerous hurdles, including a leadership change in early 2021 when Patel took over.

The game's design shifted from a single seamless world to an "open zone" format. Despite these struggles, Avowed received critical acclaim and strong initial sales, leading Patel to suggest that more content, including DLCs or a sequel, could be in the pipeline. 

The development parallels drawn between Avowed and Redfall highlight the different paths taken by their respective studios under Microsoft's ownership. While Arkane Austin faced difficulties without internal intervention, Obsidian had the flexibility to reevaluate and reboot Avowed, reflecting its ambitious multi-project approach. This enabled Obsidian to foster a rich game with engaging combat and meaningful player choices, true to the spirit of Pillars of Eternity.

author: Jonathan Bolding
title: An autobattler designed by Magic: The Gathering creator Richard Garfield is coming in March
description: Vanguard Exiles calls itself "a boardgame that can't be a boardgame."
content:
**Vanguard Exiles Gameplay Trailer - YouTube Watch On**

Vanguard Exiles, the latest game from Magic: The Gathering designer Richard Garfield, is set to enter early access on March 11, developed by The Tea Division. This autobattler is described as "revolutionary" in its genre, promising a unique competitive strategy experience with new scenarios every round.

The game board rearranges itself each round, requiring players to navigate their squads to maintain territory and survive. While it has a complex ruleset, players can enjoy the game without understanding every detail, as it provides post-round victory chances.

Garfield emphasizes the blend of tabletop and digital design in Vanguard Exiles, stating, “The variety offered by the game is exciting... Like with Magic: the Gathering and Keyforge, Vanguard Exiles is deeply interesting.”

A demo is currently available on Steam, allowing players to battle AI opponents and learn the basics. The full PvP mode and complete unit roster will launch with the early access version.

You can find Vanguard Exiles on Steam.

author: Jonathan Bolding
title: There's gonna be a 1 vs many board game based on 2001: A Space Odyssey
description: Take your turn, HAL.
content:
The beloved Stanley Kubrick film *2001: A Space Odyssey* is getting a new tie-in board game where one player embodies HAL 9000, attempting to kill the other players who are frantically trying to disable HAL’s malfunctioning systems aboard a spaceship. The game accommodates 3-5 players and lasts about 30 minutes. HAL’s objective is to shut down life support or three critical ship systems, while players work to input three logic sequences to deactivate HAL. Each player has a unique ability based on their character, and HAL gets multiple turns, creating an uneven playing field.

The game is designed by Phil Walker-Harding, known for popular games such as *Sushi Go* and *Sushi Go Party!*. *2001: A Space Odyssey* will be published by Maestro Media, recognized for games like *The Binding of Isaac: Four Souls* and a Smurfs tabletop roleplaying game. The board game is scheduled for release on June 20.

author: Jordan Ramée
title: D&D 5e Is Fully Represented In Solasta 2, For Better And Worse
description: Solasta: Crown of the Magister, a D&D-inspired game that closely follows the rules of the tabletop game's fifth edition, evidently released too soon. The 2021 RPG released to favorable reviews but didn't break into the mainstream. But now we live in a post-Ba…
content:
**Solasta: Crown of the Magister II** is a D&D-inspired RPG that adheres closely to the rules of Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition. Following its predecessor’s lukewarm success, the game is launching in a more favorable context, especially after the success of Baldur's Gate 3, which has elevated the profile of dice-based games.

In an hour-long demo, **Solasta II** showcased its strict adherence to D&D 5e rules. Unlike Baldur's Gate 3, which allows players to drink health potions as a bonus action, Solasta II requires players to choose between actions, consistent with traditional tabletop rules.

The combat system in Solasta II feels engaging, with tactical elements like using a Rogue's cunning action to dash and set up for sneak attacks. The game emphasizes resource management, tracking ammunition and presenting risk-versus-reward scenarios during resting periods that can affect future storylines.

Players control a party of four adoptive siblings—dwarf, elf, human, and gnome—on a quest connected to their family's legacy, facing an ancient threat. Despite the demo providing only a glimpse of the plot, the voice acting is impressive, and the characters are expressive, adding emotional depth to the scenes.

Notably, each party member in Solasta II is fully voiced and participates in conversations, enhancing the roleplaying aspects compared to other RPGs where only one character typically speaks. Overall, the demo suggests that Solasta II could cater well to fans of the D&D experience while offering a unique gameplay structure.

author: Jeremy Peel
title: It's time we talked about how wild it is to be a pedestrian in GTA 5
description: GTA is a high concept experiment in tripping over your physics-enabled feet, conducted at the highest level of blockbuster entertainment.
content:
In the docklands of Los Santos lies an unassuming building that serves as the clubhouse for the local chapter of the Lost, where Angel Kenney, a notorious criminal with a lengthy rap sheet, is located. The scene inside is tense; the tight corners and angles of the clubhouse give it a deathtrap quality, making it difficult to extract her without complications. 

The narrative shifts to a comedic moment while attempting to enter the clubhouse, highlighting the awkward controls and character movement in GTA Online. The author finds themselves unprepared for the chaotic situation, reminiscent of classic slapstick humor, losing their character's heavy body armor under gunfire in a clumsy maneuver.

This discussion leads to a comparison with the development of Assassin's Creed, where the team sought to capture the freedom of exploration found in GTA. They aimed to create a character-driven movement system, contrasting the controlled physics of driving in Rockstar games. 

In GTA, players experience a distinct lack of precision common in other third-person action games. Characters are subject to the same physics as vehicles; therefore, moving through the world requires an understanding of acceleration and inertia. Unlike more conventional games, where players have complete control over character movement, navigating Los Santos demands awareness of momentum and turning dynamics, often leading to chaotic outcomes.

author: lauren@pcgamer.com (Lauren Morton)
title: Too many RPGs don't get that 'choices that matter' isn't just about cause and effect, but Avowed does
description: I want choices that matter to me, not just to the game.
content:
You're the creative director for an upcoming RPG and reveal exciting features to an eager audience, emphasizing "choices that matter." Obsidian's latest RPG, Avowed, delivers on this promise by providing dialogue options that allow players to roleplay in meaningful ways, creating choices with potential repercussions and fun moments, even if their impact isn't immediately clear.

In contrast, the previous game, Dragon Age: The Veilguard, felt overly focused on making the player aware of their choices' consequences, which sometimes diluted their significance. Avowed, however, presents a wide array of interesting dilemmas that resonate deeply, such as deciding the fate of a mysterious meteorite or how to respond to characters in morally complex situations.

These thoughtful choices, whether they have tangible outcomes or not, contribute significantly to the gameplay experience, enhancing player engagement and investment in the story. Avowed excels in making every decision feel important, allowing players to truly feel like their choices shape the narrative.

author: Rick Lane
title: Atomfall dev says Rebellion's open world shooter has 'some experimental stuff' that can have a 'huge influence' on the game world: 'It might work out. It might not'
description: "I'm looking forward to finding out."
content:
Rebellion's upcoming game, Atomfall, has drawn comparisons to Stalker due to its open-world setting in a post-nuclear disaster zone. Lead designer Ben Fisher mentioned in an interview that the game will feature experimental elements, such as hidden events that can significantly alter the game's world state. These events can be triggered or missed by players, influencing enemy populations and overall game dynamics.

Fisher emphasized that Atomfall was designed as a more challenging experience, with an aim to provide players a sense of open freedom through less overt quest design. Players are intended to feel more like detectives, uncovering clues rather than following rigid quest lines.

PC Gamer editor-in-chief Phil Savage, who previously tried the game, appreciated the investigative elements but found the combat somewhat lacking, describing it as "a little bit janky and generally unrefined." With the game set to launch on March 27, fans are hopeful that improvements have been made to the combat system.

author: Fraser Brown, Jeremy Peel
title: A Skyrim dev broke the game before launch when they made thousands of tiny ants cast individual shadows: 'Why is the game running so slow?'
description: Always blame the bugs.
content:
Bethesda RPGs are known for their intricate details that enhance the immersive experience of the game world. Former Bethesda producer Jeff Gardiner emphasized that it’s not just about actions like committing a crime, but about the surrounding living world that reacts to players' actions.

After 15 years with Bethesda, Gardiner founded Something Wicked Games. He shared experiences from his time at Bethesda, noting that while teams had the freedom to explore creative ideas, this sometimes led to challenges during the game development process. 

One such challenge was related to the butterflies in Skyrim, which were programmed to follow players carrying flowers. This feature strained the game's performance due to the extensive processing required. Similarly, ants added to the game inadvertently caused issues with shadow casting, significantly impacting rendering performance.

Despite these challenges, Gardiner reflects positively on his time at Bethesda, appreciating the creative freedom the team had, enabled by the trust of their parent company, Zenimax. This autonomy was crucial for fostering creativity within the team.

author: tyler@pcgamer.com (Tyler Wilde)
title: 'These kids do not care about romance': Game devs want to know what today's teens want, and surveys say sex and romance isn't it
description: Young people want stories about friendship more than romance, say researchers and industry execs.
content:
Surveys indicate that today's youth prefer stories about platonic friendships and social groups over romance and sex, prompting game developers to adapt to these trends. At the D.I.C.E. Summit, game studio founder Sharon Tal Yguado and Roblox VP Tami Bhaumik discussed their findings and observations on adolescent media consumption.

A significant observation is that many young people feel lonely, with 73% of those aged 16 to 24 reporting feelings of isolation. This loneliness is attributed to various factors, including social media and global issues. However, Yguado noted that teens care about values such as safety, kindness, and spiritual connection, challenging the stereotype of superficiality.

Research from UCLA's 2024 Teens and Screens report revealed that "romance and/or sex" ranked 15th out of 21 content preferences for adolescents, while "content that doesn't include sex or romance" was 8th, and "friendships and social groups" ranked 5th. The "nomance" trend is on the rise, with 51.5% of adolescents desiring content focused on platonic relationships in 2023, increasing to 63.5% in 2024. Additionally, the percentage of teens believing that sexual content is unnecessary for storytelling rose from 47.5% to 62.4%.

Despite concerns about youth's disinterest in romance, mainstream video games typically include minimal sexual content compared to other media. The growing focus on platonic themes may reflect broader societal changes rather than a generational shift away from romance.

author: Mark Delaney
title: While We Wait For State Of Decay 3, This Punishing New Zombie Game Is Hitting All The Right Notes
description: I've long appreciated State of Decay as the exciting middle ground between an approachable zombie game like Days Gone or Dead Rising, and unforgiving survival sims like DayZ and Project Zomboid. No series or game that I know of has found that same middle grou…
content:
their best. Stealth is crucial, as just a single zombie can lead to disaster. 

Each gameplay session begins with selecting two characters from a diverse cast, reflecting varied backgrounds and skills that influence survival strategies. Similar to State of Decay, characters possess unique stats, including passive buffs and debuffs, and the ever-looming threat of permadeath adds a layer of tension. Effective resource and time management are essential; players must navigate the day-night cycle, assigning tasks while ensuring characters rest and maintain their health.

Set in the 1980s U.S., the game features stylized environments that stand in contrast to more muted scenes typical of many zombie narratives. Players can explore horizontally designed levels, balancing the need to scavenge for resources with the urgency of returning home safely. Resource management becomes critical, especially when character conditions—like exhaustion or incompetence—come into play. The experience in *Into The Dead: Our Darkest Days* promises a blend of strategy, survival, and narrative depth, offering a fresh take on the zombie genre reminiscent of previous popular titles while standing confidently on its own.

author: andy.chalk@pcgamer.com (Andy Chalk)
title: Marvel Rivals was reportedly almost cancelled because the CEO of NetEase didn't want to pay Disney for the licenses
description: And who can blame him, really?
content:
**Main Article Content:**

Marvel Rivals is a major success, recently surpassing 40 million players, but its existence was once uncertain. According to a Bloomberg report about developer NetEase and CEO William Ding, discussions about canceling the game occurred before its release. Ding reportedly had concerns about paying Disney for Marvel character licenses and even suggested replacing them with original designs to save on costs, a move that ultimately wasted time and resources.

Despite the success of Marvel Rivals, NetEase has faced challenges, including layoffs at its Seattle studio and cuts to funding for other projects. The report indicates that these layoffs are also impacting operations in China, where NetEase may not release major games in 2026.

Ding is encouraging a focus on games with mass-market appeal, such as the mobile game Eggy Party, which are expected to generate substantial recurring revenue. While some within NetEase question Ding’s leadership style and frequent changes in direction, the overarching trend in the industry emphasizes the importance of connecting games with players' desires for shared experiences and engagement.

If NetEase can maintain the momentum of Marvel Rivals, it could become a significant source of revenue for the company.

author: Zack Zwiezen
title: Marvel Rivals Says Popular Third-Party PC Plugin Is 'Cheating Software' And Bans It
description: Today, Marvel Rivals launched its big mid-season update, adding two new characters, a fresh map, and some balance tweaks. But the developer behind the online character shooter also warned PC players to stop using a popular piece of software, as it believes it…
content:
Today, Marvel Rivals launched its mid-season update, introducing two new characters, a fresh map, and various balance tweaks. However, developer NetEase warned PC players against using a third-party overlay plugin called Blitz, which it considers cheating.

NetEase expressed concerns about Blitz, stating it injects itself into the game and provides players with confidential information, including damage and healing statistics, as well as abilities of opponents. As such, the developer announced it would no longer allow the use of this program during gameplay, deeming it cheating software.

Players who have used Blitz recently will not face immediate punishment, provided they refrain from using it in future games. NetEase urges players to avoid any third-party add-ons to maintain fairness in the game.

In response, Blitz has temporarily paused its Marvel Rivals overlays, indicating it is working on ways to return.

author: Blair Marnell
title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater Site Is Counting Down To An Announcement
description: Earlier this week, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 had an update that teased the return of Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. In a skate park map called The Grind, there is a banner with the THPS logo and the date "03.04.25." Now, the official site for Tony Hawk's Pro Skater …
content:
Earlier this week, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 had an update that teased the return of Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. A skate park map called The Grind features a banner with the THPS logo and the date "03.04.25." The official Tony Hawk's Pro Skater site now has a countdown clock to March 4, 2025, suggesting an imminent announcement.

The first Tony Hawk's Pro Skater game was released by Activision in September 1999. Tony Hawk has been in contact with Activision about celebrating the franchise's 25th anniversary, and he confirmed that the series will continue. 

Possible future announcements may include another remake like 2020's Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1 + 2, or a brand-new game, as the last original title was 2015's Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5. There are predictions that a new game could arrive as soon as this summer.

Additionally, former Activision Blizzard CEO Bobby Kotick mentioned that Hawk was living in his car when he made the deal for the first Pro Skater game, highlighting the journey of the franchise as it looks towards the next generation of consoles.

author: Ethan Gach, Kenneth Shepard, Carolyn Petit, Zack Zwiezen, and John Walker
title: Kotaku’s Weekend Guide: 5 Good Games We Can't Get Off Our Minds
description: Spring is almost here. I can practically feel it quietly blossoming between the 25-degree overnight lows and the desperate last flurry of snowflakes coating my driveway this week. Until then, we’re feasting on 2025's early bounty of games ahead of some heavy …
content:
Spring is approaching, with a blend of cold temperatures and the last bits of snow reminding us of winter. In the gaming world, sales data from January 2025 reveals that players are mostly engaging with older titles rather than new releases. Donkey Kong Country Returns was the only new game to make it into the top 20, and it is a port of a 2010 Wii game. 

Final Fantasy VII Rebirth and Spider-Man 2 saw increased activity due to their PC releases, but there has been a notable decline in new gaming hardware purchases. This drop is attributed to the age of the Nintendo Switch and the PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S being past their peak. Anticipation builds for upcoming titles like Monster Hunter Wilds and Assassin’s Creed Shadows, while various other games, including indie titles, continue to keep players engaged.

author: andy.chalk@pcgamer.com (Andy Chalk)
title: Peripheral maker Corsair says Grand Theft Auto 6 is coming to PC in 'early 2026,' then immediately yoinks it back
description: Nothing to see here?
content: Grand Theft Auto 6 is expected to release on consoles in the fall of this year, with a PC version anticipated in early 2026. This was mentioned by Corsair Gaming's vice president Ronald van Ween during a recent financial call, where he suggested that the game would likely follow the series' historical pattern of delayed PC releases. However, shortly after his comments surfaced, Corsair retracted the statement, clarifying that van Ween was merely speculating and that they had not received any official PC release timeline from Take-Two or Rockstar.

author: andy.chalk@pcgamer.com (Andy Chalk)
title: Peter Jason, the voice of Fallout 2's famous drill sergeant and Dizzy in the Gear of War games, has died
description: Jason had a long career as a character actor in film and television and frequently collaborated with John Carpenter, but to us he'll always be Sergeant Dornan.
content:
Character actor Peter Jason, known to gamers as Drill Sergeant Dornan in Fallout 2 and Dizzy in the Gears of War series, has died at the age of 80, with cancer reported as the cause. 

Jason had a prolific career with over 260 credits dating back to the 1960s. He had notable roles in films such as 48 Hrs, Prince of Darkness, and HBO's Deadwood series. He frequently collaborated with horror director John Carpenter, appearing in films like They Live and In the Mouth of Madness. 

Mourning his death, Carpenter described Jason as "one of the great character actors in cinema" and a dear friend. In the gaming community, he was fondly remembered for his roles in Gears of War and Fallout 2, with the Gears account honoring him as "a legend."

author: Tyler Colp
title: Nintendo’s Alarmo has broken out of its cage and is now available at Best Buy
description: Nintendo’s Alarmo is currently $99.99 at Best Buy, the same price it costs at the Nintendo store — but you can get it without a subscription. All of us have dreamed of waking up to the ding ding dinging of Mario collecting coins or the wet rat-a-tat-tat of gu…
content:
Nintendo’s Alarmo is currently available for $99.99 at Best Buy and the Nintendo store, without the need for a subscription. This alarm clock plays music and sound effects from popular Nintendo games, such as Super Mario Odyssey, The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, and Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, to wake you up with a nostalgic jolt.

The Alarmo features a red design and offers 35 different wake-up “scenes.” It has various alarm settings, including Steady Mode, which increases the intensity of sounds, Gentle Mode for consistent noises, and Button Mode for snooze functionality. Additionally, it can play soothing sounds to help you fall asleep and log your sleep patterns to provide insights into your rest habits. The device is also capable of playing Doom.

author: Ethan Gach
title: Yakuza Creator's New Action Game Could Be In Trouble
description: Long-time Sega producer Toshihiro Nagoshi left the Sonic publisher in 2021 to form a new studio under Chinese gaming giant NetEase. After establishing the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series as one of the best action-RPG sandboxes around, he had the chance to start u…
content:
Long-time Sega producer Toshihiro Nagoshi left Sega in 2021 to form a new studio under NetEase. He began work on an open-world action drama, building on the success of the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series. However, recent reports indicate that NetEase is scaling back its gaming investments, particularly in Japan. This shift means that funding and marketing support for Nagoshi's project may be limited. As a result, even if the game is completed, it might not receive the promotional rollout that fans expect.

NetEase had also acquired Grasshopper Manufacture, the studio behind Let It Die and No More Heroes, but plans for new projects there may also be in jeopardy due to this new strategy. This retreat is seen as part of a wider trend of volatility at the Chinese gaming publisher.

author: Ethan Gach
title: Marvel Rivals Was Reportedly Almost Canceled Over Licensing Fees In Last-Minute Pivot That Cost Millions
description: Marvel Rivals has been a huge hit for NetEase. The Chinese publisher recently reported the free-to-play hero shooter had over 40 million players. But the Overwatch clone was almost canceled over the licensing fees the company would owe to Disney for using its…
content:
**Marvel Rivals**, a free-to-play hero shooter by NetEase, has garnered over 40 million players, but its development faced significant obstacles related to licensing fees owed to Disney for using comic book characters. According to a Bloomberg report, NetEase's CEO, William Ding, considered canceling the project due to the costs associated with popular characters like Wolverine and Spider-Man. 

At one point, developers were instructed to create original hero designs, resulting in millions in unused work, though NetEase disputes this narrative, highlighting its long-standing partnership with Marvel since 2017.

Despite the challenges during development, including potential financial strain from licensing agreements that may reach hundreds of millions for various titles, Marvel Rivals launched successfully. However, it comes amid a broader trend of reduced gaming investments from NetEase, including recent layoffs of Marvel Rivals' developers in Seattle, while the core team remains in China.

author: Steven Petite
title: Nintendo Alarmo Now Available At Major Retailers - Mario Will Wake You Up For $100
description:
Nintendo Alarmo - Interactive Alarm Clock 
 $100 
See at Best Buy 
Nintendo Alarmo is now available to purchase for $100 at Best Buy. The Nintendo-themed interactive alarm clock first released in October at the Nintendo Store, but you needed a Switch Onlin…
content:
Nintendo Alarmo is now available for purchase at Best Buy for $100. This interactive alarm clock, themed around Nintendo, initially debuted at the Nintendo Store in October, requiring a Switch Online membership for purchase. Originally set to be released at major retailers in March 2025, Alarmo has arrived earlier than expected and is currently only available at Best Buy and the Nintendo Store, with the anticipation that other retailers like Walmart, Target, and GameStop will stock it soon.

The alarm clock boasts a Mario-red color, a dynamic front display, and a built-in speaker. Users can select from various Nintendo characters and games to wake them up, featuring content from five initial Nintendo Switch titles: Super Mario Odyssey, The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, Animal Crossing: New Horizons, and more recently added titles like Splatoon 3 and Pikmin 4. There are over 40 scenes that can play alongside the corresponding game tracks when the alarm goes off, with an option for the volume to gradually increase.

Alarmo also has interactive features, such as a built-in motion sensor that allows users to snooze alarms with gestures. Additionally, it can remind users of the time throughout the day with music and track sleep patterns. The clock is powered via an included USB-C cable, and a coin battery retains settings during power outages or relocations.

Nintendo plans to provide free updates to Alarmo, including new scenes, but Wi-Fi connectivity is required for downloads. Notably, there's an unofficial capability to play Doom on the device.

author: Ana Diaz
title: All vault locations in Fortnite and how to open a vault
description: Vaults are a new kind of location added to Fortnite as part of Chapter 6 Season 2’s heist shenanigans. The new map has several vaults filled with loot scattered throughout it. Some are located in a specific building, like a bank, whereas a special kind of vau…
content:
the train cars. Locate the vault on the train, which will be found inside one of the cars.

To open a vault on a train, you will still need to use thermite. Once you find the vault door, place the thermite on it just like you would for a building vault. Remember, this will trigger an alarm, so be ready for other players and NPCs to respond.

After placing the thermite, either wait for it to go off or use the Plasma Burst Laser to speed up the process by damaging the glowing parts of the door. Once the door is open, you can access the loot inside.

In summary, there are five major vault locations in Fortnite for Chapter 6 Season 2, with both building vaults and moving vaults on trains. To open a vault, players need thermite and possibly a Plasma Burst Laser or another explosive item to gain access to the loot, all while being cautious of potential threats from other players and NPCs.

author: Eddie Makuch
title: TLOU Boss Says He Never Felt Confident With A Game He's Led Except For This One
description: Neil Druckmann is one of gaming's biggest names, and he's helped write and direct games in the critically and commercially successful franchises like The Last of Us and Uncharted. But Druckmann isn't always confident in what he's making while he's making it--…
content:
Neil Druckmann, a prominent figure in the gaming industry, has contributed to successful franchises like The Last of Us and Uncharted. During a recent speech at the DICE Summit, he expressed that he only felt "confident" while working on 2009's Uncharted 2: Among Thieves. For other projects, he experienced doubts and felt uncertainty about their success, which he learned to overcome.

Druckmann highlighted that the size and budget of a project contribute to his anxiety, as there is no guaranteed formula for success. He emphasized the importance of following instincts and trusting the team's advice. The creative process at Naughty Dog involves collaborating on ideas and iterating repeatedly, with the understanding that the initial concepts are often not the best. This approach requires discarding work at times, which can be frustrating but is essential for overcoming doubts.

He noted that maintaining a schedule is crucial to the workflow, as it helps the perfectionist tendencies within the team. Currently, Druckmann is directing Naughty Dog's new project, Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet, and is also involved in developing The Last of Us 3 and Season 2 of The Last of Us for HBO, set to premiere in April.

author: Michael McWhertor
title: Marvel Rivals’ Blade addition appears imminent
description: Marvel’s vampire hunter Blade looks like a lock for Marvel Rivals, based on multiple in-game teasers including a look at the character’s model. Blade’s addition to NetEase Games’ team-based hero shooter would certainly be in line with the Marvel Rivals’ curre…
content:
Marvel's vampire hunter Blade is likely set to join Marvel Rivals, based on multiple in-game teasers. Blade has been featured in various artworks and recently appeared on the cover of the Daily Bugle newspaper within the game. A trailer for the new map, Empire of Eternal Night: Central Park, provides further hints of his arrival, including a sneak peek at his in-game model and a depiction of a tabletop game featuring Blade, Dr. Strange, and Squirrel Girl teaming up against Dracula.

Although there has been no official announcement regarding Blade's addition, it seems inevitable. With the recent addition of the Fantastic Four to the game, fans anticipate that Blade may arrive soon, possibly with the launch of Season 2 in April. Currently, Marvel Rivals includes 37 characters, although NetEase Games indicated that future seasons may not feature the same number of new heroes as season 1.

author: Amelia Emberwing
title: The Bond Franchise Sale to Amazon MGM Is Probably Bad News... But Here Are Some Ways It Could Work
description: Amazon MGM Studios now has creative control of the James Bond franchise. The news concerned fans — including us — but here are some ways the shift could end up working out for the spy and his followers.
content:
In a significant development for James Bond fans, Amazon MGM Studios has gained full control of the 007 franchise from long-time producers Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli. This shift raises concerns about the potential expansion of the franchise into a broader "universe," similar to Marvel and Star Wars, amid Amazon’s ambitions and significant financial investment.

Broccoli expressed apprehension over Amazon possibly expanding too quickly or casting a high-profile actor as Bond. Amazon has previously attempted to launch its own spy franchise with the Russo Brothers' produced "Citadel," but these efforts have not achieved the same acclaim as other Amazon successes.

Interestingly, Amazon has already ventured into Bond-themed programming with "007: Road to a Million," a reality show that aired in 2023. Despite the mixed reception, it reflects Amazon's interest in exploring the 007 brand beyond traditional film.

Moreover, while there is limited history of Bond in television, adaptations and formats have occurred over time. Currently, there have been no announcements indicating that Amazon plans to abandon film entirely, and it is likely that they will continue to honor the legacy of the franchise, potentially exploring various character arcs beyond the titular character.

author: Ian Walker
title: The Pokémon Company reaches settlement with copycat developer. No, not that one. A different one
description: The Pokémon Company announced on Feb. 19 its reaching of a mediated settlement with Guangzhou Maichi Network Technology and Khorgos Fangchi Network Technology, the Chinese developers of a mobile game that blatantly infringed intellectual property rights by us…
content:
The Pokémon Company announced on Feb. 19 that it reached a mediated settlement with Guangzhou Maichi Network Technology and Khorgos Fangchi Network Technology, Chinese developers of the mobile game Pocket Monster: Remake, which infringed on Pokémon intellectual property by using character and creature designs from the franchise.

The Pokémon Company aims to protect its intellectual properties and ensure that users worldwide enjoy Pokémon content without concerns. Pocket Monster: Remake, released in 2015, reportedly earned over $40 million by 2016. The Pokémon Company filed a lawsuit against six companies involved in the game’s creation in 2022, seeking over $72 million in damages and a public apology. The Shenzhen Intermediate People’s Court ruled in favor of The Pokémon Company in September 2024, ordering $15 million in damages, but the two companies appealed.

A settlement was reached during a follow-up hearing in December 2024, which included the granting of a public apology. In their joint statement, Guangzhou Maichi Network Technology and Khorgos Fangchi Network Technology acknowledged their infringement and the unfair competition caused by their actions, apologizing to The Pokémon Company and its rights holders.

While the specific settlement figure was not disclosed, the companies indicated they faced significant economic and reputational consequences from the legal proceedings.

Additionally, The Pokémon Company's patent infringement case against Palworld developer Pocketpair is ongoing, with changes made to the game to address alleged imitation of patented mechanics related to Poké Balls.

author: Joshua Wolens
title: XCOM's creator wants to know where XCOM 3 is just as badly as you do: 'I'm sure there's an audience for it'
description: You and me both, Julian.
content: XCOM 2 was released nearly nine years ago and received widespread acclaim, leading many, including original creator Julian Gollop, to wonder about the absence of XCOM 3. In a recent interview, Gollop expressed his confusion over the lack of a sequel, noting that while strategy games remain a niche market, there is still a demand for XCOM-style gameplay. He highlighted that much of the innovation in strategy games now comes from indie developers, mentioning titles like Factorio and Tactical Breach Wizards. While some newer games like Jagged Alliance 3 and Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader incorporate XCOM-like mechanics, the anticipated XCOM 3 is still missing from the gaming landscape.

author: George Yang
title: Marvel Rivals' Cancelation Was Considered Before Release, NetEase Making Changes - Report
description: Amidst the abrupt layoffs of some employees who worked Marvel Rivals, it's now reported that the game's cancelation was considered prior to its release, which is a surprising revelation, given it has already surpassed 40 million players.According to Bloomberg…
content:
Amid the abrupt layoffs of employees from Marvel Rivals, recent reports indicate that the game's cancellation was considered before its release, even though it has surpassed 40 million players. 

According to Bloomberg, discussions about canceling the game arose due to NetEase CEO William Ding's reluctance to pay Disney for using popular Marvel characters. He proposed replacing them with NetEase's own hero designs, a change that ultimately did not occur, resulting in significant wasted resources. A NetEase spokesperson disputed this account, affirming the company's close relationship with Marvel since 2017.

The layoffs of US-based developers occurred despite the game's success, with NetEase stating they were made for organizational reasons and to enhance development efficiency. This adjustment affected the design team in Seattle, which is part of a larger global effort for Marvel Rivals.

In addition, Ding has reportedly halted support for numerous other gaming projects, leading to expectations that NetEase's China-based studios may not have major releases next year. The company has also paused operations at several acquired developers, leaving fewer than 60 employees in its overseas studios as investments outside China are curtailed.

Toshihiro Nagoshi, creator of Yakuza/Like a Dragon, joined NetEase in 2022 and formed his own studio. While project details remain undisclosed, his studio, along with others like Suda51's Grasshopper Manufacture, has been given time to complete ongoing work, but no future funding will be provided.

NetEase's first western studio, Jackalyptic Games, is developing a Warhammer MMO, which has received positive feedback from other publishers. Despite this, Game File reports that NetEase is looking to offload its non-Chinese studios and plans to divest from many of its overseas teams, which may lead to further studio closures lacking additional funding.

The tumultuous landscape of the video game industry continues into 2025, as studios face employee layoffs and shut downs.

author: Rebekah Valentine
title: NetEase Founder Reportedly Almost Canceled Marvel Rivals Because it Didn't Use Original IP
description: NetEase's Marvel Rivals can't be described as anything less than a hit, netting ten million players in just three days from launch and raking in millions for developer NetEase in the weeks since. But a new report suggests that NetEase CEO and founder William …
content:
NetEase's Marvel Rivals has achieved significant success, attracting ten million players within three days of its launch and generating substantial revenue for the developer. However, a report from Bloomberg reveals that CEO William Ding almost canceled the game due to his hesitance in using licensed intellectual property, specifically Marvel characters. Ding attempted to persuade the development team to create original designs instead, which would have likely cost the company millions.

As part of a broader effort to streamline operations, Ding is cutting jobs, closing studios, and retracting investments abroad, aiming for a more focused portfolio to counteract a recent decline in growth and remain competitive against rivals like Tencent and MiHoYo. Recently, the Seattle team for Marvel Rivals was laid off for "organizational reasons." Ding's strategy now indicates that he considers games generating less than hundreds of millions annually not worth pursuing, though a company spokesperson refuted the notion that specific revenue thresholds are applied to assess new game viability.

Internally, employees report challenges stemming from Ding's unpredictable leadership style, which includes rapid decision-making, pressure for extended working hours, and a significant turnover in project direction. This instability has led to concerns that NetEase might not release any new games in China in the upcoming year.

NetEase's retreat from game investments aligns with broader industry struggles, marked by layoffs, project cancellations, and the failure of several high-profile titles despite high expectations.

author: Ethan Gach
title: Don't Sleep On This Indie Roguelike Cult Hit And Its First Major Update In Five Years
description: Star of Providence is a bullet hell roguelike shooter that mostly went under the radar when it came to Steam back in 2017. But since then, it’s won over a devoted fan following, including the YouTuber videogamedunkey, who liked it so much he decided to help r…
content:
**Star of Providence** is a bullet hell roguelike shooter that gained a loyal fan base since its initial release on Steam in 2017. Originally titled "Monolith," the game was rebranded to avoid legal issues with Warner Bros. Games. The indie title is known for its striking retro art style, diverse enemies, and engaging boss fights, complemented by a chiptune soundtrack.

Recently, the game received a significant update and was relaunched on the Nintendo Switch under the Bigmode label, thanks in part to YouTuber videogamedunkey. The update, titled *Into Oblivion*, includes:

- 2 new upgrades
- 1 new playable character
- 5 new normal enemies
- More new bosses than enemies
- 13 new unique weapons
- 20 new cartridges
- 43 new keywords, including those exclusive to certain weapons
- A rework of the loop mechanic, capped at 13 loops
- A rework of the Skully playable ship
- Introduction of the Gauntlet, a sub-branch offering valuable rewards
- New "Boss Rushes"
- Hundreds of new room layouts with varied hazards
- Massive balance changes and performance optimizations

This revitalization marks a second chance for *Star of Providence*, which had previously garnered attention when it made videogamedunkey’s best games list in 2018. The game's design encourages exploration and mastery, allowing skilled players to complete it in about 35 minutes, making it well-suited for the Switch platform.

author: Mark Delaney, Phil Owen
title: How To Open Fortnite Vaults In Chapter 6 Season 2 - All Vault Locations
description: Fortnite's long winter season has come to a close, and now we're hip-deep in another of Fortnite's favorite twists on its battle royale formula: Chapter 6 Season 2 is a new heist season. Like we saw in Chapter 4, the battle royale map is now full of giant vau…
content:
Fortnite's Chapter 6 Season 2 has introduced a heist theme, featuring vaults filled with high-quality weapons and gadgets, along with a new currency called Dill Bit. There are four vault locations: Lonewolf Lair, Crime City, Seaport City, and Masked Meadows. These vaults spawn in every round, and players should target those farthest from the Battle Bus flight path for the best loot.

To open these vaults, players need to use thermite explosives, which can be looted from enemies, chests, or found in heist duffel bags. Planting thermite on the vault door alerts nearby NPCs and other players, as it burns through the door's weak spots. Players can speed up the process by placing more thermite or shooting the glowing spots. The Plasma Burst Laser weapon is particularly effective for this.

Additionally, there's a vault on a train equipped with automated turrets. Players can acquire thermite by destroying these turrets, and the train vault opens more quickly than stationary vaults, though it also prompts the spawn of guard NPCs.

For team-based play, coordinating roles can enhance the heist experience and increase success rates.

author: Zack Zwiezen
title: After Working On Oblivion Fan Remake For A Decade, Its Devs Aren't Worried About The Rumored Official One
description: The modders behind the highly anticipated Skyblivion PCmod aren’t concerned that Bethesda might be gearing up to release its very own official Oblivion remake. Instead, the team is just “excited” to finally finish its project and get it in the hands of gamers…
content: The modders behind the highly anticipated Skyblivion PC mod are excited to finish their project and get it into the hands of gamers. Skyblivion is a fan remake of Bethesda’s 2006 RPG, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, using Skyrim’s engine. The project began as a port in 2012 and has evolved into a full remake, set to launch later this year. Despite rumors of an official Oblivion remake being in the works, lead modder Kyle “Rebelzize” Rebel stated that it doesn’t affect their project and hopes that it leads more people to try Skyblivion. Rebel expressed pride in the journey of creating the mod over the past decade and excitement to see others enjoy their hard work.

author: Joshua Wolens
title: Done with apocalypses, the new game from XCOM creator Julian Gollop is a bright, Brutal Legend-style action-strategy inspired by Pikmin and Clash Royale
description: Chip 'n Clawz vs The Brainioids has aliens, but that's where the XCOM comparisons stop.
content:
Julian Gollop's upcoming game, **Chip ‘n Clawz vs The Brainioids**, marks a departure from his previous titles, embracing a more upbeat tone and gameplay style. Unlike his well-known games such as **XCOM** and **Phoenix Point**, this new project features no random number generation (RNG) or turn-based mechanics. The game combines a vibrant art style reminiscent of Fortnite with action-strategy elements similar to Brutal Legend.

Gollop acknowledges that long-time fans may find it challenging to adapt to this new direction, noting that the humor might be the only familiar aspect for them. Despite initial reservations, the gameplay offers a fun and frenetic experience as players manage their characters through combat and strategy.

In this game, players can choose to play as Chip or his robotic partner Clawz, with each character offering unique abilities. The gameplay involves on-the-ground action, alongside base building and troop management, allowing players to experience a blend of direct combat and tactical decisions as they navigate through levels, engage with enemies, and gather resources.

The visuals and narrative draw inspiration from early comics and the classic **Mars Attacks**, presenting a world recovering from an alien invasion. Players fulfill the role of heroes as they clean up the remnants of an alien armada, balancing the need for strategy with fast-paced gameplay.

author: robin.valentine@futurenet.com (Robin Valentine)
title: RPGs like Avowed need to stop letting me steal everything that isn't nailed down
description: When I literally take the bread off a starving man's plate, I feel like I might deserve a telling off.
content:
In *Avowed*, the experience of survival in the Living Lands is marred by a common RPG mechanic: the ability to steal items from NPCs without consequence. Players encounter desperate individuals suffering from natural, criminal, or political woes, yet these characters remain passive as players pilfer their belongings, undermining immersion. The author expresses frustration that, despite the effort put into creating an engaging world, games frequently overlook the implications of theft in the narrative.

The author acknowledges the game mechanics that encourage a kleptomaniac playstyle, where players are incentivized to collect materials and unique items from NPCs. Ignoring this aspect would hinder gameplay, leading to a disconnection between the player's actions and the story. The article cites other games, like *Kingdom Come: Deliverance* and *Baldur's Gate 3*, which feature more nuanced theft systems with consequences. However, not all games have the resources to implement such systems.

Ultimately, the author questions why lootable items are so plentiful in games that lack a reactive theft system. They argue that if a theft mechanic isn't feasible, it may be better to limit the presence of items in NPC homes entirely, suggesting that engagement can be maintained through other means, like side quest rewards. The piece ends on a contemplative note, wondering if these frustrations are overblown in the grand scheme of game design.

author: Billy Givens
title: How To Have A Little Respec In Hit RPG Avowed
description: Part of the appeal of a large-scale role-playing game is customizing your character in ways that compliment your preferred playstyle. But as you play through a sprawling game like Avowed, you may find that the way you like to approach combat or dialogue evolv…
content:
**How to Respec Your Abilities and Attributes in Avowed**

If you're looking to change your character build in Avowed, you can easily reset your attributes and abilities without restarting the game or losing significant progress. Here’s a guide on how to do it.

**Respeccing Process**

1. **General Notes**: You can’t reset individual attributes or abilities; you must reset all of them at once. The initial respec is inexpensive, but the cost increases with each subsequent respec.

2. **Respec Attributes**: 
   - Open the Character screen.
   - Hold R (PC) or Y (Xbox) to reset all attributes and reapply your points.

3. **Respec Abilities**: 
   - Open the Abilities screen.
   - Hold R (PC) or Y (Xbox) to reset all abilities, allowing you to select a new loadout of skills. You can also reset companion abilities from this menu.

With your new build set, you’re ready to explore the vast world of Avowed.

author: Kenneth Shepard
title: Ex-Dragon Age Producer Asks People To Stop Harassing Developers, Gets Predictable Response
description: When you’ve been on the internet as long as I have, you get the distinct displeasure of watching cycles of toxicity repeat themselves ad nauseam, usually over things that don’t matter in the grand scheme of things. The world is on fire and rather than devotin…
content:
Mark Darrah, former director and producer of the Dragon Age series, recently released a YouTube video titled “Your $70 Doesn’t Buy You Cruelty.” In the video, he discusses the unfortunate trend of online harassment directed at video game developers over dissatisfaction with their work. Darrah emphasizes that while criticism is valid and can aid in improving games, it often devolves into personal attacks targeted at lower-level developers who had little control over the final product. 

He argues that a culture of cruelty has emerged, where dissatisfied customers express their frustration not through constructive feedback but through harassment and even celebrating job losses among developers. Darrah calls for empathy and compassion, encouraging people to express their opinions responsibly and avoid targeting individuals within the development teams. He underscores that while gamers are entitled to their opinions about games they purchased, it's crucial to voice these critiques without resorting to cruelty. 

The comments section of his video, however, reflects the contentious environment of online discussions, with many responses attempting to justify the very behavior Darrah condemns.

author: Blair Marnell
title: PUBG Creator Thinks Players Will Initially Hate His Next Game
description: In late 2019, PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds creator Brendan Greene offered the first glimpse of his next game, Prologue: Go Wayback. Unlike PUBG, Prologue isn't a shooter or a battle royale. Instead, it's a survival game that pits players against bitterly col…
content:
In late 2019, Brendan Greene, the creator of PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds, introduced his next project, Prologue: Go Wayback. Unlike PUBG, Prologue is a survival game that challenges players with harsh elements and a difficult environment. Greene anticipates that some players will find the game's extreme difficulty frustrating at first but believes they will eventually appreciate it.

The objective in Prologue is to survive long enough to reach a randomly located weather station on an 8x8 km map. Players must scavenge for gear while managing hunger and thirst. The game features "millions" of potential maps, ensuring a unique experience with each playthrough. Prologue currently has no release date, but early access is expected in the second quarter of the year.

Greene's team at PlayerUnknown Productions plans to develop Prologue as part of a long-term project that includes another game called Project Artemis. Meanwhile, PUBG publisher Krafton is exploring AI-powered teammates for PUBG and is also working on a spin-off titled PUBG: Blindspot.

author: Ethan Gach
title: It Took 10 Years For The Makers Of This Blatant Pokémon Rip-Off To Apologize And Pay $15 Million
description: Pocket Monster: Remake was released back in 2015. The mobile game played almost identically to Pokémon, even using the art, names, and move sets form the existing franchise. A decade later, The Pokémon Company has finally reached a settlement with the Chinese…
content:
The Pokémon Company has reached a settlement with Guangzhou Maichi Network Technology Co., the developers of the mobile game Pocket Monster: Remake, which had been a direct copy of the Pokémon franchise. In a public statement, the company acknowledged their copyright infringement and the economic losses it caused to the rights holders. They apologized for their actions, stating that their game had caused significant reputational damage.

Pocket Monster: Remake, which was released in 2015, closely mimicked the original Pokémon games, including the characters and artwork. Although the Pokémon Company did not pursue legal action until 2021, a court ruling in September 2024 ordered the developers to pay approximately $15 million in damages, significantly less than the $72 million originally sought. The game has now been removed from the market, and the developers acknowledged their substantial economic and reputational losses, stating they have learned from their mistakes.

author: Tomas Franzese
title: Marvel Rivals Bans A Popular Third-Party Plugin, But Don't Worry If You've Used It
description: NetEase is getting more aggressive when it comes to cracking down on the use of third-party plugins while playing Marvel Rivals. It's now banning the use of an application called Blitz, although NetEase is being lenient in that it won't ban players who previo…
content:
NetEase is intensifying its crackdown on third-party plugins in Marvel Rivals, specifically banning the application Blitz. A notice was issued on February 21, declaring that while using Blitz—a tool that provides competitive insights like damage statistics and ability predictions—will no longer be allowed, players who previously used it will not face penalties if they stop using it.

NetEase stated, "we deem this program as cheating software and will no longer allow its use during gameplay." However, they reassured players that there would be no retroactive penalties for past usage, urging players to avoid any third-party plugins to maintain the game's integrity.

Marvel Rivals, which is free on PC, PS4, and Xbox Series X|S, recently surpassed 40 million players and added The Thing and Human Torch as new heroes. However, despite its success, NetEase laid off the game's North American developers earlier this week.

author: Elie Gould
title: Is This Seat Taken? is an upcoming adorable puzzle game all about dealing with stinky triangles and snotty squares, and just trying to make everyone happy
description: Some of these shapes need to take a shower.
content:
**Is This Seat Taken?** is a calming puzzle game where players arrange anthropomorphic shapes (triangles and squares) in various locations like restaurants, buses, and cars to maximize their happiness. Each shape has specific requirements, such as preferences for sitting next to windows or avoiding noisy neighbors. The goal is to fulfill these differing needs, which can become increasingly complex in later levels.

The demo includes five puzzle locations: a taxi, a limo, a theatre, a bus, and a concert, each with unique layouts and challenges. Some areas, like the limo, are easier due to ample space, while others, like the concert, pose significant challenges due to tight constraints and multiple requirements.

Amidst the puzzles, there’s a light narrative involving one shape aspiring to become an actor, although players can choose to focus solely on gameplay without engaging with the story. Although there’s no release date yet, the demo offers a satisfying 20-minute experience that hints at more to come. If you enjoy stress-free puzzle games, the free demo is worth trying out.

author: Jeremy Laird
title: 'A massive, massive moment of wow.' Microsoft CEO predicts AI-generated games are a 'CGI moment' for the industry
description: Nadella also says the company wants to be in gaming for gaming's sake: "Flight Simulator was a product long before we even built Windows."
content:
Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella recently discussed the company's new AI-powered game generation platform, Muse, which he likens to the transformative impact of CGI in the film industry. In an interview, Nadella highlighted Muse as the first World and Human Action Model (WHAM), a generative AI model capable of creating game visuals and actions.

Nadella envisions a future where users can simply describe their ideal game scenario and have it generated instantly, though he acknowledged that current limitations, such as resolution, may hinder this vision. Despite being a research platform, he believes Muse's influence on the gaming industry is imminent, with plans to generate a catalog of games for users to play.

He emphasized Microsoft's long-standing commitment to gaming, pointing out that the company's first game, Microsoft Flight Simulator, predates Windows. Nadella also shared his perspective on measuring AI's success, suggesting that economic growth, rather than abstract notions of AI becoming self-aware, should be the benchmark. He believes in the importance of achieving significant economic growth, contrasting it with current modest rates.

Nadella expressed a belief that the AI industry will not lead to a single dominant player, suggesting that large markets can sustain multiple winners. Overall, he conveys a sense of optimism about the future of gaming with AI while also addressing the broader economic implications of such technologies.

author: Ethan Gach
title: Two Incredible Star Wars Games Are Free On Mobile If You Ignore Google's Malware Warning
description: Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 1 and 2 are currently available to download for free on mobile, with just a few catches. The first is you have to have an Android smartphone. The second is you have to ignore Google’s warning that you might be downloadin…
content:
**Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 1 and 2** are currently available to download for free on mobile, but there are a couple of requirements. You need an Android smartphone, and you must disregard Google’s warning about downloading “harmful” files. If you can navigate these hurdles, you can enjoy two of the best Star Wars RPGs ever made.

This opportunity arises from the **Epic Games Store**, which is providing remastered versions of both original Xbox-era games as part of its initiative to create a cross-platform shopping experience. After years of legal battles, Epic launched a competing app store on mobile devices, which included returning popular games like Fortnite and Fall Guys.

While this initiative has made strides, challenges remain. Although EU regulations have opened up app stores, iPhones in the U.S. still don't permit such access. Android devices can access the Epic Games Store, but Google continues to evoke caution about potential risks.

Downloading KOTOR 1 and 2 involves navigating warnings about harmful files, but Epic has provided guides to ease the process. While it may deter some users unfamiliar with the setup, it represents significant progress for mobile gaming.

author: Evan Campbell
title: How Fallout 76 Went From A Disappointment To Delight For A Former Project Lead
description: It's not exactly a secret that Fallout 76's launch was a mess in 2018. Yet, almost seven years later, the online RPG has become a major success for Bethesda and Microsoft--and the source of pride for a former project lead on the game who witnessed first-hand …
content:
Fallout 76's launch in 2018 was troubled, but nearly seven years later, the online RPG has become a significant success for Bethesda and Microsoft. Jeff Gardiner, a former project lead on the game, shared his experiences with PC Gamer, highlighting the stress of developing a live-service game and the negative feedback he faced personally.

Gardiner left Bethesda in 2021 after the release of the Wastelanders expansion. He noted that the initial poor reception affected team morale, making it his responsibility to instill pride in the development team. Despite the challenges, he takes pride in Fallout 76, considering it one of his top career achievements due to its eventual turnaround from failure to success.

The game continues to evolve, with recent updates including the Gleaming Depths expansion, which allows players to interact with pets, and plans to introduce the ability to become a ghoul later this year. Fallout 76 is available on Game Pass.

author: Tomas Franzese
title: A DC Comics Video Game Based On Dark Nights: Metal Releases In March
description: While recent reports have shown that WB Games is struggling and titles like Wonder Woman are years away from release, a new game based on DC Comics, DC: Dark Legion, is launching on PC, iOS, and Android next month.DC: Dark Legion is based on the Dark Nights: …
content:
A new game based on DC Comics, DC: Dark Legion, is set to launch on PC, iOS, and Android on March 14. The game is inspired by the Dark Nights: Metal comic book storyline and allows players to recruit superheroes and villains to combat multiversal threats. 

Gameplay includes building rooms and training heroes at the Batcave, as well as exploring locations like Gotham City, Metropolis, and Atlantis for real-time strategy battles and PvP. Developer FunPlus released a cinematic trailer and is currently offering pre-registrations on the App Store and Google Play, promising special rewards for reaching pre-registration milestones:

- 1 Million – Weapons Optional Gift Pack (1 of 5 iconic weapons)
- 2 Million – 100x Green Mother Boxes (chance to obtain heroes or resources)
- 5 Million – Champion Gift Pack (unlock 1 of Batman, Wonder Woman, Harley Quinn, The Flash, or Green Lantern)
- 10 Million – 10x Draws from The Bleed (contains full heroes)

DC: Dark Legion aims to provide fans of DC video games with a new experience, launching soon on multiple platforms.

author: Hayley Williams
title: Some Games Run Better On Older GPUs Than On Nvidia's New 50-Series Cards
description: Nvidia's new 50-series graphics cards just aren't as good at running certain older games as previous hardware generations were, some PC gamers have discovered. With its latest generation of GPUs, Nvidia has quietly removed support for PhysX, a physics simulat…
content:
Nvidia's new 50-series graphics cards have been found to perform worse with certain older games compared to previous generations due to the removal of support for PhysX, a physics simulation technology. Users on Reddit and Nvidia forums noted that PhysX is now disabled by default and, when enabled, runs on the CPU, causing significant performance issues in games designed for GPU-enhanced PhysX.

Nvidia confirmed that it has discontinued PhysX support alongside its end of support for 32-bit CUDA applications for the 50-series and future generations. This change impacts a range of older games that relied on PhysX for realistic physics simulation.

PhysX was acquired by Nvidia in 2008 and was used in various popular titles, including Borderlands 2 and the Batman: Arkham trilogy. Despite being mostly defunct in new games, many gamers expressed disappointment over the lack of warning regarding its discontinuation. A group on the Resetera forums has compiled a list of nearly 50 affected games and their performance when using the CPU for PhysX.

Gamers who frequently play older titles may prefer to stick with previous Nvidia generations, as the 40-, 30-, and 20-series will still support 32-bit CUDA applications. Additionally, the new 50-series GPUs are currently hard to find.

author: Darryn Bonthuys
title: Former Sony Boss Confirms What We Were All Thinking About PlayStation PC Ports
description: A couple of years ago, the idea of PlayStation-exclusive games being ported to PC would have seemed highly unlikely, but times have changed. Insomniac's Spider-Man games, Housemarque's Returnal, and the Horizon series are just a few of the big PlayStation pro…
content:
Sony has increasingly ported PlayStation-exclusive games to PC, a trend that started around 2020 with notable titles like Insomniac's Spider-Man games, Housemarque's Returnal, and the Horizon series. Former PlayStation boss Shuhei Yoshida expressed in an interview that releasing games on PC allows Sony to reach a new audience, particularly in regions where consoles are less popular, such as China. He described these ports as a cost-effective way to generate additional income, helping fund new titles amidst rising game development costs.

Yoshida noted that PC ports can convert new players into franchise fans who might later invest in a PlayStation console. The next planned PC port is The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered, following the earlier release of Marvel's Spider-Man 2. Since leaving Sony in January after 38 years, Yoshida has addressed various industry topics, including the rise of live-service games and the absence of a Bloodborne remaster.

author: Ethan Gach
title: Ex-Amazon Gaming Exec Explains Why No One Has Beaten Steam
description: A surprising contradiction sits at the heart of PC gaming: the medium’s most open platform is nevertheless dominated by a single storefront. That storefront belongs to Valve, it’s called Steam, and despite plenty of challenges in the two decades since it laun…
content:
PC gaming is dominated by Valve's Steam, despite being an open platform. Ethan Evans, a former VP at Amazon's Prime Gaming, discussed his experience in trying to disrupt Steam's hold on the market. He acknowledged that Amazon, even though it was significantly larger, failed to challenge Steam effectively.

Evans identified three initiatives Amazon undertook to gain market share: acquiring the small game store Reflexive Entertainment, developing its own game store leveraging Twitch’s popularity, and launching the Luna game streaming service. However, none of these efforts made a significant impact. Other companies like EA, Ubisoft, and Bethesda also struggled with their proprietary launchers. The Epic Games Store, despite offering many free games, still primarily serves as a launcher for Fortnite.

Evans attributed Amazon's failure to understand what made Steam appealing to users. He emphasized that it served as a store, social network, library, and trophy case all in one, which created a strong user habit. Amazon's assumption that its size alone would attract users was misguided; it needed to provide a compelling reason for players to switch.

Despite valid criticisms of Steam—such as poor moderation and discovery tools—its ecosystem remains effective, with sales and a strong user base. Steam's dominance continues to shape the gaming landscape, making it challenging for new platforms to gain traction.

author: Elie Gould
title: Players are already finding creative solutions to Prologue: Go Wayback's grueling difficulty: 'You could just chug gasoline'
description: Keep an eye out for those blackberries.
content:
**Prologue: Go Wayback! Summary**

"Prologue: Go Wayback!" is a challenging survival roguelike game that encourages players to think creatively about survival tactics. During playtests, players discovered innovative ways to use available resources, such as using a ferrous rod to create embers for light when lost in the dark. The game requires players to make difficult decisions about what to carry due to limited backpack space. 

Players can utilize the environment strategically; for example, one player ingeniously turned on an oven to catch a log on fire as a heat source. The game allows for unique player strategies and shortcuts, although some previously available methods, like consuming gasoline, have been patched out. 

Blackberries are a key resource, providing 100 calories each, making them far more beneficial than apples. Players are encouraged to gather as many blackberries as possible to prevent starvation. The developers are actively working to balance the game, aiming to make it both challenging and accessible to new players while maintaining replayability for veterans.

author: Fraser Brown, Jeremy Peel
title: Fallout 76's former project lead says it's still his favourite game he worked on, but the initial reception was demoralising: 'I got yelled at in an Apple Store, I'll never forget'
description: Jeff Gardiner oversaw the game's troubled launch, as well as the start of its redemption arc.
content:
Fallout 76 has significantly improved since its rough launch, benefitting from the popularity of Amazon's Fallout TV show and a series of transformative free updates. Initially criticized for being an online-only Fallout game without NPCs, the game's project lead, Jeff Gardiner, emphasized the importance of not just improving the game for players but also boosting team morale.

Gardiner noted that working on a live service game is stressful and that player disappointment affected him personally. His approach involved listening to his team and incorporating their ideas, which was crucial for the game's evolution. The pivotal update, Wastelanders, transformed Fallout 76 into a more complete experience by introducing NPCs, quests, and new factions, greatly enhancing the game.

Wastelanders launched in 2020, marking a high point for Gardiner before he left Bethesda. He reflected on the challenges and successes of working on Fallout 76, stating it became his favorite project due to its remarkable turnaround. Gardiner is now developing an open-world RPG, Wyrdsong, at Something Wicked Games, alongside other former Bethesda designers.

author: Jacob Kienlen
title: How to Connect Your PlayStation VR2 Headset to a PC: Step-by-Step Guide
description: Make the most of your PlayStation headset.
content:
If you want to connect your PlayStation VR2 headset to a gaming PC for SteamVR, you'll need a $60 adapter released by Sony, compatible with modern gaming PCs that meet the headset's minimum specifications. While it is marketed as a plug-and-play device, additional setup may be required based on your PC configuration.

**Requirements for Connection:**

1. **Adapter**: Ensure you have the adapter.
2. **Bluetooth**: Your PC should have Bluetooth 4.0 connectivity.
3. **Cable**: A spare DisplayPort 1.4 cable is necessary.
4. **Power**: Access to an available AC power outlet.
5. **Software**: Install both the PlayStation VR2 and SteamVR apps on Steam.
6. **Charging**: The Sense controllers require USB-C charging ports and cables. Alternatively, a Sense controller charging station is available for $50.

author: Ryan McCaffrey
title: Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories & The Envisioned Land Might Be the Series' Coziest JRPG Yet – Hands-On Preview
description: After spending over six hours in Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories and the Envisioned Land gathering resources, doing Sailor Moon-esque magical dancing rituals, and riding around on a motorbike, there’s quite a bit to be optimistic about, even if what …
content:
Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories and the Envisioned Land aims to innovate within the long-running Atelier JRPG series. After six hours of gameplay, it offers engaging combat, improved visuals, convenient crafting, and a new building system that personalizes the game world. While the story and characters appear somewhat conventional, the game enhances its core pillars: exploration, combat, and synthesis.

Combat has received a substantial rework, introducing action-based mechanics that allow for perfect parries, dodging, and varying attack ranges. Although early encounters were easy, the challenge increased when the player was under-leveled, requiring attention to enemy patterns and timing.

Exploration has been refined with tools like a stun gun, ziplines, and a motorcycle for better navigation. The synthesis system remains complex but offers an "auto mode" for quicker gameplay.

A notable addition is the ability to build and customize settlements, drawing inspiration from games like Animal Crossing. This feature encourages players to explore and develop their own space within the game, enhancing the overall experience.

author: Zoë Hannah
title: In this house, any game can be a co-op game
description: My husband and I have been playing a lot of Portal 2 — arguably the best couch co-op game of the modern era, despite the success of Hazelight’s It Takes Two, which also changed the genre forever. I could name a few more, and that’s about it. I’m not talking j…
content:
My husband and I have been playing a lot of Portal 2 — arguably the best couch co-op game of the modern era, despite the success of Hazelight’s It Takes Two. We’re not just limited to traditional co-op games; we've adapted various games into co-op experiences.

We were inspired by our experience with The Quarry, a playable film that allows for local co-op play. Instead of using the intended setting, we collaborated on decisions while one of us controlled the game, often pausing to discuss clues or previous dialogue. We played through The Quarry several times, with one person holding the controller and the other prepping dinner.

We applied the same approach to Overboard!, an inverted mystery game designed for replayability. These non-co-op co-op games, typically narrative-driven with decision-making elements, have become our go-to for weeknights and are perfect for date nights in the winter. Sharing these experiences enhances our connection and allows us to bond over the stories, evoking strong emotions, like when we cried at the end of Firewatch.

author: andy.chalk@pcgamer.com (Andy Chalk)
title: 'A wizard is never late, nor is he early, he arrives precisely when he means to,' but it's a different story for hobbits because Tales of the Shire is delayed again
description: The happy hobbit life sim is now slated to come out at the end of July.
content:
The cozy hobbit life sim, "Tales of the Shire," has been delayed and is now set to launch on July 29. The game is described as "Stardew Valley but with happy little hobbits," featuring a 3D environment that emphasizes cooking over farming. Players will explore the town of Bywater, embark on quests, and enjoy a charming art style.

This is the second delay for "Tales of the Shire," which was originally slated for the second half of 2024. Concerns have been raised about the game’s identity and mechanics, as evidenced by a demo reviewed by PC Gamer’s Kara Phillips, who found it "clumsy" and lacking substance.

Developer Wētā Workshop is committed to enhancing the game, stating their goal is for it to feel like "a warm hug from Middle-earth." They assured players that every detail, from foot-hair styles to cakes, will be carefully crafted.

Stay tuned for life in The Shire this summer.
